docs.lead_paragraph: A SERIES of nonbinding recommendations from a panel. A vaguely worded radio interview. Some nonspecific comments by his new treasurer. Those are the tea leaves from which observers in Trenton are left to divine Gov. Jon S. Corzine's plan to fix the state's daunting and intractable multibillion-dollar budget gap this year. Little seems clear, other than the general realization that the solution will be painful.
docs.abstract: Political observers in Trenton are trying to divine Gov Jon Corzine's plan to fix state's multibillion-dollar budget gap; some say state residents seem more ready than ever to accept painful measures, including cuts to popular programs and increases in taxes and fees; size of gap, estimated by Corzine to be as high as $6 billion, could be more than ten times that amount when long-term debt and state pension and health care obligations are included; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A SERIES of nonbinding recommendations from a panel. A vaguely worded radio interview. Some nonspecific comments by his new treasurer.     Those are the tea leaves from which observers in Trenton are left to divine Gov. Jon S. Corzine's plan to fix...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thomas R. Suozzi, the Nassau county executive and a self-styled renegade Democrat, announced Saturday that he was challenging Attorney General Eliot Spitzer for his party's nomination for governor, running as an underdog who will benefit to an unusual degree from business leaders who have been sued by Mr. Spitzer and New Yorkers who dislike his tactics. Mr. Suozzi's bid, declared at a boisterous rally in his Long Island hometown here, stands as a direct affront to the New York Democratic Party, which is behind Mr. Spitzer with rare unanimity in the hope of electing the first Democrat as governor since Mario M. Cuomo was defeated in 1994.

headline.main: L.I. Democrat Takes On Spitzer In Governor Race

docs.abstract: Nassau County Executive and self-styled renegade Thomas R Suozzi will challenge New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer for Democratic gubernatorial nominations; will rely to unusual degree on business leaders who have been sued by Spitzer and New Yorkers who dislike his tactics; pledges to work to reduce property taxes, overhaul Medicare, settle state education funding lawsuit and give more money to schools; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Thomas R. Suozzi's bid is a direct affront to the New York Democratic Party, which is behind Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.
docs.section_name: Health; Education; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: An emergency room doctor filed a bias complaint with the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities earlier this month against St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury after the hospital denied his request for health coverage for his civil-union partner. Alan J. Couture had requested coverage in October for his partner Robert McDonald, the same month Connecticut put its civil union law into effect, said Dawne Westbrook, Dr. Couture's lawyer.
docs.abstract: Dr Alan Couture files complaint with Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities after St Mary's Hospital in Waterbury denies his request for health coverage for his civil-union partner; St Mary's reportedly has self-funded health insurance plan, which operates under federal guidelines and is not required to adhere to state mandates; photo (S)
docs.snippet: An emergency room doctor filed a bias complaint with the Connecticut Commission on Human Rights and Opportunities earlier this month against St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury after the hospital denied his request for health coverage for his...

docs.lead_paragraph: RICK DOTY is a 30-year veteran of Caterpillar, the big tractor and earth-moving equipment manufacturer. He is paid $23.51 an hour as a machinist, and he receives additional benefits worth almost as much. That sets him far above newly hired workers consigned to a much lower wage scale. To these fellow workers, Mr. Doty, who is also a local union leader, struggles to justify an inequality that he helped to negotiate.
docs.abstract: Article in series Rewriting the Social Contract: Barriers to Middle-Class Pay; longstanding wage advantage that manufacturing workers enjoy over their counterparts in services or construction is shrinking fast as older workers depart, at Caterpillar and at other companies; United Auto Workers union at Caterpillar reluctantly accepted two-tier contract that provides significantly lower wages and benefits for newly hired employees; new second tier is as much as $20 per hour below cost for older workers; trade-off is promise of manufacturing revival at long last in old Rust Belt, as new hires come aboard at much lower labor costs; even healthy and highly profitable companies like Caterpillar are engaging in practice of two-tier wage structure; longstanding presumption that factory workers at successful companies can achieve secure, relatively prosperous middle-class life for themselves and their families is evaporating; Caterpillar chief executive Jim Owens says lowering wages has allowed company to add jobs; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: The longstanding presumption that factory workers at successful companies can achieve a secure, relatively prosperous middle-class life is evaporating.

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES I wish that the whole world celebrated a Teachers' Day. It would demonstrate our gratitude to the magnificent teachers we have had during our lives. I think of Ms. Bratt, my third-year Latin teacher in high school, who had us all dress in togas and read Cicero's Catilinarian orations. I think of my great first-year Humanities and Contemporary Civilization teachers at Columbia, Mr. Fiering and Mr. Rothschild, and my disturbingly on-target teacher of Eastern European history, Mr. Rothstein.

headline.main: What Is an Oil Company, Anyway?

docs.abstract: Ben Stein column scores those who denounce oil companies for their huge profits, especially Exxon Mobil; says Exxon Mobil's executives do not reap millions from company; holds its executives pay employees decently, take care of their medical bills even in retirement and do not drain hundreds of millions of dollars out of employee pay to make themselves rich; says if Exxon Mobil executives become rich, they do it through long years of making company profitable, not through vampirizing their employees; says about 41 percent of Exxon Mobil stock is owned by retirement funds, private, public and individual retirement accounts; adds company is owned by us; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: SOMETIMES I wish that the whole world celebrated a Teachers' Day. It would demonstrate our gratitude to the magnificent teachers we have had during our lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Monday proposed that over-the-counter cold medications that contain pseudoephedrine and ephedrine be available only by prescription. The ingredients can be used to make methamphetamine, the highly addictive illegal drug also known as meth. Mrs. Rell also proposed stiffer penalties for selling and manufacturing methamphetamine, as well as for possessing the paraphernalia to make or use it.

headline.main: A Stiff Proposal For Cold Medicines

docs.abstract: Connecticut Gov M Jodi Rell proposes over-the-counter cold medications that contain pseudoephedrine and ephedrine be available only by prescription; ingredients can be used to make methamphetamine; Rell also proposes stiffer penalties for selling and manufacturing meth as well as for possessing paraphernalia to make or use it (S)
docs.snippet: Gov. M. Jodi Rell on Monday proposed that over-the-counter cold medications that contain pseudoephedrine and ephedrine be available only by prescription. The ingredients can be used to make methamphetamine, the highly addictive illegal drug also...

docs.lead_paragraph: BOXING MESI RETURNS TO THE RING -- The heavyweight Joe Mesi, who has not fought for two years because of a medical suspension, will face Ron Bellamy, a 41-year-old journeyman, on April 1 in Puerto Rico. The Puerto Rican Boxing Commission granted Mesi (29-0) a license last week after he passed medical exams. Mesi, 32, sustained at least two subdural hematomas -- brain bleeds -- in a unanimous decision over Vassiliy Jirov in Las Vegas in 2004. The injury led to Mesi's indefinite suspension by the Nevada Athletic Commission, which was overturned in December. DE LA HOYA TO FACE MAYORGA -- Oscar De La Hoya will end a long layoff with a fight against Ricardo Mayorga, the World Boxing Council super welterweight champion, on May 6 in Las Vegas. It will be De La Hoya's first fight since he was stopped by Bernard Hopkins in the ninth round on Sept. 18, 2004. De La Hoya said he would fight twice more before retiring. COLLEGE BASKETBALL TEXAS TECH WOMEN'S COACH TO RESIGN -- Coach Marsha Sharp, 53, who won an N.C.A.A. women's basketball title at Texas Tech and turned the school into a perennial power, said yesterday that she would resign at the end of the season. Sharp's season has been marred by health problems and by Tech's dropping out of the top 25 for the first time in more than a decade. AUTO RACING NASCAR SUSPENDS HMIEL -- The driver Shane Hmiel has been suspended from competition indefinitely by Nascar after failing a third substance-abuse test. Hmiel is the 26-year-old son of the longtime crew chief and team official Steve Hmiel, and was first suspended in September 2003 after failing a substance-abuse test. PRO FOOTBALL NINERS WIN A COIN TOSS -- The San Francisco 49ers won a coin toss yesterday for the sixth pick in the N.F.L. draft in April, followed by the Oakland Raiders. Both teams finished with 4-12 records last season, tying for the sixth and seventh picks. They also tied on strength of schedule. VINATIERI MAY SAMPLE FREE AGENCY -- Adam Vinatieri may get a chance to test free agency after the New England Patriots declined to protect him with the franchise player tag. Vinatieri, who has kicked two Super Bowl-winning field goals for the Patriots, was twice the team's franchise player, including last year, when he was paid $2.5 million. This year, team would have to offer $3 million. The Patriots have until March 3 to sign Vinatieri. BASEBALL BAGWELL AND ASTROS REMAIN AT ODDS -- The standoff between the Houston Astros and Jeff Bagwell took the expected awkward turn yesterday when Bagwell arrived at spring training. He had surgery in June on his right shoulder, and the Astros argue that Bagwell is too hurt to play. They filed an insurance claim in January to recoup about $15.6 million of the $17 million Bagwell is guaranteed this season. Bagwell, 37, fielded grounders, made light throws and spent most of the team's first full-squad workout in the batting cage. He shook hands with the owner Drayton McLane, who said he wanted to meet again with Bagwell in the next few days. CLASSIC HIRES MINOR LEAGUE UMPIRES -- Unable to work out a deal with unionized major league umpires, organizers of the World Baseball Classic announced crews yesterday that are made up largely of minor league umpires who regularly fill in at the major league level. Bob Davidson, Tom Hallion and Ed Hickox were the notable names among the 31 umpires hired for the tournament. The three were among the 22 who lost their jobs during a 1999 labor dispute. CYCLING LANDIS MAINTAINS HIS LEAD -- George Hincapie joined Juan Jose Haedo of Argentina as a double-stage winner while Floyd Landis kept the race lead yesterday in the Tour of California. Hincapie again used his Discovery Channel teammates' strong support to sprint to victory in the 105.3-mile fifth stage in 3 hours, 52 minutes, 2 seconds. STEROIDS PROBATION FOR KORCHEMNY -- Remi Korchemny, the track coach in the Balco doping scandal, was sentenced to a year of probation yesterday by a federal judge who said she was moved by stories of his tireless coaching of track athletes, many of them amateurs. Korchemny, 73, of Castro Valley, Calif., also was ordered to undergo mandatory drug testing and avoid all contact with the other defendants in the Bay Area Laboratory Co-Operative firm case.
docs.abstract: Heavyweight Joe Mesi will face Ron Bellamy in bout (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday the Supreme Court agreed to consider the constitutionality of the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act, a measure passed overwhelmingly by Congress in 2003 but rejected as unconstitutional by three federal appeals courts for not providing exceptions for a woman's health. Meanwhile, ignoring the advice of anti-abortion tacticians who doubt that the time is right for a frontal challenge, legislators in South Dakota have voted to send a bill outlawing virtually all abortions careering through the courts toward the new roster of justices.

headline.main: Abortion has returned to center stage, but should the dialogue be changed? And if so, just how?

docs.abstract: Peter Steinfels Beliefs column notes that abortion has returned to center stage in American consciousness; says that public remains ambivalent, as revealed by several polls on question; finds that both sides of issue are taking approach to reducing number of abortions through medical, financial and educational measures (M)
docs.snippet: The abortion issue is back, one might say, except that it has never gone away.

docs.lead_paragraph: A small group of National Security Agency officials slipped into Silicon Valley on one of the agency's periodic technology shopping expeditions this month. On the wish list, according to several venture capitalists who met with the officials, were an array of technologies that underlie the fierce debate over the Bush administration's anti-terrorist eavesdropping program: computerized systems that reveal connections between seemingly innocuous and unrelated pieces of information.

headline.main: Taking Snooping Further; Government Looks at Ways To Mine Databases

docs.abstract: Bush administration is looking at ways to mine databases in its anti-terrorist eavesdropping program: computerized systems that reveal connections between seemingly innocuous and unrelated pieces of information; tools government officials are looking for are new, but their application would fall under well-established practice of data mining: using mathematical and statistical techniques to scan for hidden relationships in streams of digital data or large databases; intelligence agencies, hardly newcomers to data mining, are using new technologies to take practice to another level; but by fundamentally changing nature of surveillance, high-tech data mining raises privacy concerns that are only beginning to be widely debated; to find illicit activities it is necessary to turn loose software sentinels to examine all digital behavior whether it is innocent or not; technology industry executives and government officials say that intelligence agency systems take techniques used by Internet-era software snoops step further, applying software analysis tools now routinely used by law enforcement agencies to identify criminal activities and political terrorist organizations that would otherwise be missed by human eavesdroppers; one such tool is Analyst's Notebook, crime investigation 'spreadsheet' and visualization tool developed by i2Inc, diagram (L)
docs.snippet: Intelligence agencies, hardly newcomers to data mining, are using new technologies to take the practice to another level.

byline.original: By JOHN MARKOFF; Scott Shane contributed reporting from Washington for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: DISRUPTIONS in the oil patch served as bookends to the debate that consumed the nation this week over ports and national security. Fannie Mae and HealthSouth took their licks, while Wal-Mart Stores tried to get out ahead of its detractors on health care. OIL PRICES SPIKE -- For oil traders, the week got off to a volatile start after attacks in the oil-rich Niger Delta reduced Nigeria's oil production sharply. Though the United States markets were closed Monday in observance of Washington's Birthday, oil futures in London jumped sharply.

headline.main: Oil Worries, and Price, Rise After Turmoil Abroad

docs.abstract: Five Days column; Nigeria's oil production was reduced sharply after attacks in Niger Delta; oil futures jumped sharply; United States Markets were closed for Washington's Birthday; Dubai Ports World expected to complete $6.85 billion purchase of Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co; agreed not to exercise control over terminal operation at six American ports; report commissioned by directors of Fannie Mae found that senior executives manipulated accounting in 1990's to meet earnings projections and ensure bonuses; report is expected to renew calls for more oversight of mortgage giant; Wal-Mart Stores chief executive H Lee Scott Jr announced changes to company's health benefits program; United States governors have criticized coverage retailer provides, saying it leaves states to carry burden of medical costs; HealthSouth agreed to pay $445 million to settle investor lawsuits after federal investigators uncovered accounting fraud; company admitted no wrongdoing; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Disruptions in the oil patch served as bookends to the debate that consumed the nation this week over ports and national security.
